Web design

Today’s tech makes it easier than ever to do it yourself. But actually sitting in front of a screen and getting a site up and running is still a lot. Folks tend to appreciate having someone who knows the ropes. Decisions like what to work on next and what can wait until after launch aren’t straightforward.

See some examples of taking a brand and painting it on the medium of the web.

Brand and site for affordable homes and community space in Underhill, VT

See it!

Brand and site for woodworking business in Upstate NY offering custom furniture, crafts and classes.

See it!

Dispensary in Western Mass. Together with CannaPlanners

See it!

Launched 10 years ago and still going strong. What started as a side project to a cabinet maker turned into a full-time gig when the site helped produce steady work.

See it!

Sites for contractors

For 6 years, I’ve was part of a marketing agency dedicated to this industry. Below is a selection of sites I created for that agency.

Charter invested in branding before coming to us and it shows. Commitment to the direction of the brand is what makes this site successful. Our story was anchored in a nautical theme, and we used supporting metaphors and imagery.

See it!

This site is the result of a strong partnership with the client. Professional photographs wildly elevate the site’s impact. The color repetition, angle, and video in the hero are the icing on the cake.

See it!

One constraint was solely using google fonts. Here, I spice things up by sneaking in a graphic of script font in a few places. The mobile design was considered upfront, during the creation of the pattern library. So, when a dev builds something like this, the responsive breakdowns are mostly complete.

See it!

We don’t see many serif fonts in this industry so this was a bit of a novelty. Designs are created in adobe XD and take advantage of their ‘smart’ components, colors, and character styles. View the site to see animations like the truck sliding in.

See it!

The client did the branding internally. I matched the trucks to the site by bringing in the curves from the logo. The site adhered to conversion principles in many places: a promotion is offered for filling out the Mini form, trust icons high on the page, photos of actual happy customers, and custom photos throughout.

See it!

Great branding is not just a logo, but a toolbox of matching design elements. This client came to us with a full toolbox. In addition, they had a rich maintenance plan brochure which gave some direction on how to use the brand. Design themes include wavey-line separators, sunbursts, subtle textures, a mascot in color and monotone, a cursive font, and a retro mascot. I also designed a maintenance plan price graphic to help users understand the offering.

See it!

This commercial client was treated differently than our more common residential owners. We limited content on the homepage and focused more on imagery.

See it!

Their logo and headquarters itself already leaned toward a retro style. I pushed it further by introducing sunbursts, stripes, and angles. This aesthetic communicates longevity and nostalgia, which results in a sense of comfort and confidence in the business.

See it!

We were able to build an entire design system using a basic crown emblem and helvetica logo. The site has background patterns, a soft welcoming palette, and bright button colors.

See it!

Although only one truck image was provided, it was surprisingly rich in design features that served as the foundation for building a tactile and trustworthy brand.

See it!

Good on ya for making it all the way down here. Send me a note if you'd like a site, or check out the branding and research examples.
